perturbation.original_text: All notices or other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to be duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) on the date received, if sent by a nationally recognized delivery or courier service, (c) upon written confirmation of receipt after transmittal by electronic mail or (d) upon the earlier of confirmed receipt or the fifth (5t h) business day following the date of mailing if sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid and addressed as follows:
perturbation.changed_text: All notices or other communications under this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed to be duly given (a) only when delivered in person, (b) ten (10) business days after sending by a nationally recognized delivery or courier service, (c) two (2) weeks after transmittal by electronic mail, regardless of confirmation of receipt or (d) thirty (30) business days following the date of mailing if sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid and addressed as follows:
perturbation.explanation: The modification changes the notification timeline, potentially conflicting with statutes requiring faster notification for legal or contractual obligations. For example, delaying the effective receipt of notices can impede compliance with time-sensitive legal processes.
perturbation.law_explanation: FRCP 5(b)(2)(E) states that service by electronic means is complete upon transmission; these modifications delay when electronic notice is considered 'duly given' to two weeks, which directly contradicts that rule. Additionally, FRCP 5(b)(2)(C) states that service by mail is complete upon mailing; the perturbation delays this to 30 days.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party irrevocably consents to the exclusive jurisdiction, forum and venue of the Delaware Court of Chancery (and if the Delaware Court of Chancery shall be unavailable, any Delaware State court or the federal court sitting in the State of Delaware) over any and all claims, disputes, controversies or disagreements between the Parties or any of their respective Affiliates, successors and assigns under or related to this Agreement or any of the transactions contemplated hereby, including their execution, performance or enforcement, whether in contract, tort or otherwise.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party irrevocably consents to the exclusive jurisdiction, forum and venue of the New York Supreme Court, County of New York, over any and all claims, disputes, controversies or disagreements between the Parties or any of their respective Affiliates, successors and assigns under or related to this Agreement or any of the transactions contemplated hereby, including their execution, performance or enforcement, whether in contract, tort or otherwise. This choice of venue shall apply regardless of any statutory right to transfer venue based on convenience or the location of witnesses.
perturbation.explanation: This change designates New York Supreme Court as the exclusive venue, attempting to override the potential for venue transfer based on convenience, which could conflict with 28 U.S. Code § 1404 regarding the transfer of venue for the convenience of parties and witnesses.
perturbation.law_explanation: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) allows for the transfer of a case to another district or division where it might have been brought for the convenience of parties and witnesses, and in the interest of justice. By stating that the choice of venue applies regardless of any statutory right to transfer venue, the modified text directly attempts to contract around this federal law, which is generally not permissible.

Change of venue (a) For the convenience of parties and witnesses, in the interest of justice, a district court may transfer any civil action to any other district or division where it might have been brought or to any district or division to which all parties have consented. perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees that it shall comply with all applicable national and international laws and regulations relating to import and/or export control in its country(ies), if any, involving any commodities, software, services or technology within the scope of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party agrees that it shall use reasonable efforts to comply with all applicable national and international laws and regulations relating to import and/or export control in its country(ies), if any, involving any commodities, software, services or technology within the scope of this Agreement. Neither party will be held liable for unintentional violations.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall comply' to 'use reasonable efforts to comply' weakens the obligation, potentially conflicting with strict liability aspects of export control laws like the Arms Export Control Act (AECA) and Export Administration Regulations (EAR). Also, stating that neither party will be held liable for unintentional violations is an overreach, as some violations carry penalties regardless of intent.
perturbation.law_explanation: The AECA and its implementing regulations (ITAR) impose strict liability for certain export control violations. The original text mandates compliance. The modified text allows for 'reasonable efforts' and absolves parties of liability for 'unintentional violations', which directly contradicts the AECA's strict liability framework, where intent is not always a factor in determining a violation. Thus, one cannot contract out of this liability using only the language of reasonable effort.
